rComments: He gives really tough homework. The tests were weird-a lot of multiple choice. I wish the tests were more problem solving because that's what we actually do all quarter. In lectures he spends a LOT of time doing algebra or evaluating an integral or something and doesn't explain the overall concept (usually). NOT good at answering questions.
He isn't very good at answering questions in class but is a decent lecturer. He uses a lot of slides and demonstrations which are helpful. Ready to help at his office hours.

Robert Johnson is a good lecturer. He really knows his material and it comes out when he teaches. He uses demonstrations almost every class. He's kind of bad at answering questions in lecture but people ask stupid ones usually anyway. If you do the homework, go to lecture (iclickers count), and study a few hours for each test you'll get an A.

Spends a bit too much time doing algebra on the board rather than explaining concepts. His grading system is fair, but its not as easy to get an A as in some other courses. Assigns homework problems that require way too much algebra, although maybe this is just the nature of this course. Quizes and final were straight forward and fair. Good prof.
He's reallllllly hard. Though if you keep up with all the materials and show concern for the course, he'll make sure you do well and at least pass.

Lectures are dry but clear--the problem is that Johnson is terrible at describing concepts, which is absolutely vital for physics. Lab was torture (often 20 hrs/wk), I tried hard not to fall asleep in there. He's alright with questions though often brushes you off. Hardest class I've taken, with the least payoff. Electronics never "clicked" for me.

Teacher definitely knows what he is teaching.  Lectures can be a bit on the dry side and you will spend some quality time with the book and prepping for midterm, but the tests are very conceptual and fair.  Interesting class, lab is dull.
